The News-Letter
Vol. IX.

January 20, 1905,

No. 6

A Hard Lesson.
"No, Frank; I do not expect you to admit
that all men are selfish. That would be asking too much; and then, you yourself will
always shine as a brilliant exception."
The man passed the reins into his right
hand and turned to the girl quickly, with
lips compressed, and an unmistakable frown
on his face. Then his mouth widened into
a smile.
"Edith, if you begin any more of your
sarcasm, I declare I'll turn the buggy into
the ditch, and set you in those blackberry
bushes. Why on earth do you talk such rot
—pardon me, but it is rot—just when I am
enjoying myself by airing my pet little
views? Moreover, you are scarcely respectful to your future lord and master."
The girl started. "Frank," she said suddenly, "how long have we been engaged?
Four months it has been, has it not? And
we are to be married in four weeks more.
Does it ever occur to you that we are making rathed rapid work of it? I have sometimes thought that it might be better, after
all, if—"
"What might be better?" He watched
her closely as her eyes fell to her left hand.
"Oh, nothing;" and he knew from the answer and the tone that coaxing would be
of no use.
"Edith, do you see those two men in the
yellow trap just ahead? Well, the one in
the gray clothes is Charlie Hanson, who sold
me this horse. I heard from a mutual acquaintance that he gave himself grand airs
after the deal, because he had got the best
of the bargain. Now, I think I'm a pretty
good judge of horses, and I'm willing to bet
that this horse is worth the money I paid
for her."
"Naturally;" said the girl, "or you would
not have paid it."
The man did not heed the interruption,
and went on, "Let's catch up to them. I

want to see what sort of a nag he's driving
to-day."
He flicked the reins on the horse's back,
and the carriages came side by side. The
two men greeted each other coldly, and presently—after the three-cornered introduction
was over—Frank threw out a feeler.
"Charlie, this is a pretty good mare you
sold me. She's speedy at times. She showed
2.32 at the track last week. Is that one
yours?" pointing to the other horse.
"Yes," was the answer. "I got her last
month, and she's rather fast. Suppose we
try them together—say to the next milehouse."
"Done," was the reply, and each whipped
up his horse.
Selfishness is a trait which manifests itself in a variety of ways. Some men it
makes conceited. Others become lazy because of it. Still other men are drawn by
it to seek an eternal good time. To the third
class belonged Frank Doane. He prided
himself on his "sporting instincts," which,
being examined, comprised solely a desire
for pleasure at the expense of anything else;
and anything else might include his friends,
his money, or, at present, the girl he was to
marry. As the light buggy was flying down
the road, almost abreast of the other team,
he forgot Edith and everything except the
fact that he had been challenged to a race,
and must do his best to win it. He did not
allow the idea of danger to enter his head.
The road was clear, he was an experienced
driver, and there could be no danger. As
for asking Edith's permission, it seemed entirely unnecessary.
He laid the whip on heavily, until the
carriage rocked like a row boat as it bounded
over stones and ruts. Yet the other horse
kept just a few yards ahead. Hanson kept
a firm hold on the reins, and looked back
over his shoulder with a smile which drove

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Doane to let his horse have full control of the
bit. The speed was frightful, and increased
every second. The mile-house was passed
in no time. The slower horse, no longer
feeling any curb, took matters entirely into
her own control, so that when a mounted
policeman shouted a caution as the flying
pair flashed by, Doane found it impossible
to check the mad pace of the mare, who was
now almost winded and covered with foam.
Hanson, however, had perfect control of his
horse, and slowed down to a walk.
Edith had not made a sound. With hands
fast gripped to the seat, and with her face
set, she was like a statue, expecting every
moment to be hurled from the buggy, but
showing not a trace of her emotions in her
features. She saw a speed-sign far down
the road come nearer, and disappear in a
blur. Vehicles were drawn off to both sides
of the driveway, and she saw the frightened
faces of the occupants and realized her danger. But danger did not occupy most of
her thoughts. She was wondering most at
the man by her side. His hat had blown
off, his eyes were straining, his whole soul
absorbed in his mad pleasure.
She was
having his whole real self revealed to her.
In the parlor, Frank Doane was the smoothest, most self-contained man to be found.
Now, he would not have heeded a pistol at
his head, so entirely had he lost control of
himself. This man was not the one she had
admired for his steady hold on himself, for
his thoughtfulness for women, and for his
bravery and gentleness. No; the creature
by her side was little better than one of the
howlIng, maddened crowd she had once seen
at a race. And she was to marry him in
a month. She shuddered at the thought.
Both Frank and the horse had by this time
gotten their fill of racing; and as the horse
was nearly run tired,. it slackened its speed.
The girl pointed to a large automobile
about two hundred yards distant, which was
rapidly approaching. As the space closed,
the horse began to step sideways and to
shy; and the buggy was slewed around and
went upon two wheels. It hung there for
a few awful seconds, and then, as the terrified animal gave a final spring, it turned
over into the ditch, tearing loose the traces,

and threw the man and woman into the
hedge beside the road. The horse continued
its flight. Neither person was much hurt,
and both rose. Edith with her silk skirt
in tatters, and Frank with a badly scratched
face. His apologies were profuse and pitiful. to hear. Miss Lawton received them
with a perfectly calm face.
"Let us get to the cars," was all she said,
and made her way through the crowd.
Doane made arrangements with Charlie Hanson, who had by this time overtaken them,
to bring the carriage home, and to look after
the horse, which had been stopped a short
distance down the road and was now being
led back. Frank had a great desire to lay
violent hands on Hanson, who, with earnest
inquiries as to whether Miss Lawton was
hurt, and sincerest regrets that he had been
so foolish as to propose the race, was quick
to offer his services to get the horse and
buggy home. Frank felt that -his position
was very uncomfortable. He knew that, in
the eyes of his fiancee, he had lowered himself irrevocably; and in the eyes of the
crowd around him he had let a horse run
away and upset a woman, so that he was
deserving of no pity. Hanson's horse had
beaten his, and this was another sting. With
a very full sense of having done a poor day's
work, and feeling very small indeed, he accompanied Miss Lawton to the electric cars.
The ride home was almost in silence. Both
had learned a lesson, and were thinking over
what they had learned. When Miss Lawton's home was reached, she extended him
her hand, saying with a smile that nettled
him, "You will pardon me if I do not ask
you to come in. I suppose I have enjoyed
the drive. Good afternoon."
The door closed in his face.
Doane called at her house that evening.
Her brother met him at the door.
"Why, Frank, Edith left just a few minutes ago for her aunt's in Washington. No,
she didn't seem to be hurt in the least. And,
by the way, she told me to give you this if
you came to-night. She said you would understand." He handed him a small pasteboard box. It contained her engagement
ring, and he understood.

The Conference of The Association of American Universities.
NE of the most important events that
have occurred recently at the University took place when the sixth
annual session of the Association of
American Universities was held here.
during the latter part of last week.
Many of the most distinguished figures in
the colleges of the United States were present as delegates from their respective Universities. Six of the delegates were presidents of universities, and the others were
professors of wide renown in their own fields
of research and teaching.
. Tile conference began on Thursday of last
week. The sessions, which were held in the
Donovan room, were not public, because the
subjects under consideration were of great
importance, and could be more thoroughly
discussed than if the public had been admitted to the meetings. After the first session the delegates were entertained at lunch
by the trustees and professors of this University. The tables were placed in McCoy Hall,
which was beautifully banked with palms.
In the evening Mr. Theodore Marburg gave
a reception for the delegates at his house on
Mt. Vernon Place.
On Friday morning the conference assembled in the Donovan room. Among the subjects discussed was that of the higher technical education and the instruction in graduate schools.
President Remsen believes
that the length of time needed to prepare
for and complete a modern professional
course is too great. In the first place, the
age of graduation from the leading colleges
in this country is becoming so high that students cannot begin their professional training until they are twenty-two or twentythree on the average. Then, too, the length
of the professional courses themselves is now
so great that some of the best years of a
man's life are taken up with preparatory
work. President Remsen believes that in so
far as it tends to prevent students from beginning their . professional or business life
until they are twenty-two or twenty-three,
the present system of college training is seriously defective.
The closing session of the conference was
held on Saturday morning and at it papers
were read on "Opportunities for Higher Ed-

0

ucation" and "Research in State Universities." President Van use of the University of Wisconsin said that he held that in
the future the State Universities would be in
a much stronger position with reference to
advanced instructtion. A number of States,
he said, are now granting large sums to their
universities for advanced instruction and research, and in the future State funds for such
purposes are sure to greatly increase in
amount.
Professor Page of the University of Virginia, gave an encouraging account of the
increase in the resources of the Southern
State Universities. The people of the South,
he said, favor strong support of such institutions.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Heroines, Heroes and Villains in Modern Fiction.
More than in price, more than in the manner of publication, more than in any particular connected plot, letter-press, or sale, has
the novel of to-day changed from its predecessor of a generation ago, in the character
of its heroine. Our mothers and fathers
used to read in their novels of heroines of
the fragile, clinging kind, who had "willowy forms, and great, trustful eyes;" heroines who could moralize ever so learnedly
on almost any abstract subject, and reinforce
their opinions by numberless quotations from
classic authors, yet who were content to be
guided, in all temporal matters, entirely by
members of the stronger sex; heroines who
fainted upon almost no provocation, wept
upon no provocation at all, and, in the last
chapter, generally accepted the hero's proposal of marriage by bursting into a flood
of glad tears, and fainting in his arms. The
hero, as befitted the Romeo of such a Juliet,
was usually strong and brave, and "full of
a quiet dignity' —a veritable oak for such a
drooping vine of a heroine to hold fast to.
The modern heroine has got bravely over
all this. No sitting at home embroidering
samplers, no poetic hours spent in painting
landscapes, or in reading sentimental poetry,
for her! She is an "athletic girl," who plays
golf and tennis, rides a bicycle, or manages
her, own automobile, and is, on the whole,
quite as well able to take care of herself, as
The "Gibson
any of her male friends.
girl," the "Christy girl," and half-a-dozen
other kinds of independent and very muscular girls, now hold the stage, from which
their elder sister, with her hoop-skirts and
vapors, has fled in dismay.
A corresponding change has taken place
in the hero. He must still be strong and
brave, but principally in a physical sense.
He must be a very paladin for dash and
vigor—equally ready to rescue a lady, shoot
down a villain, or play the part of a king.
When he was at college, he was, of course,
captain of the 'varsity crew, or of the foot-

ball team! Of course, also, he had, and still
has, an infinite contempt for books! The
very first achievement of the hero of Richard
Harding Davis' latest novel, "Captain Macklin," was to get himself expelled from college.
Nor has the evolution of the villain been
less rapid or far-reaching than that of the
other principals in the story. No longer do
we meet with the scheming Shylock, or the
loathsome Uriah Heep, any more than we
meet with the womanly Portia, or the gentle
Agnes Wakefield. The crafty, serpent-like
kind of villain has given place to a villain
moulded from much the same .knock-medown-and-drag-me-out sort of material as
the hero is. The up-to-date villain glories
in making midnight attempts to abduct the
heroine, in attacking the hero with a band of
cut-throats, and in comporting himself generally in such a manner that the hero may
have plenty of opportunity to show his mettle. Ile is equally as ready as the villain of
old, to lie, steal, murder, or do anything else
that is evil; but he is, in addition, the possessor of a personality of the most dare-devil,
brigand-like type—just as a villain should
be in these strenuous times. He nearly always has to be killed in the last chapter, by
the hero, in order to be gotten rid of.
In the matter of personal appearance, heroines, heroes, And villains have all changed
less than in any other particular. Though now
strong and buxom, the heroine is still the
possessor, in most cases, of a "face which is
a perfect oval," "rose-bud lips," a "silvery
voice," and "rebellious curls." The hero
is tall and broad-sohuldered, usually has
curly hair, and, especially with women novelists, has the "profile of a Greek god." Villains still have "a cast in one eye," or are
"hatchet-faced;" but, on the whole, they
exhibit a far greater variety of types than
either the hero or heroine.
A Literary Critic.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE INTER-CLASS DEBATE.
NE of the many subjects of talk, among

O

the little groups which gather in the
corridors of McCoy Hall, is the coming inter-class debate. This will take place
during the second week in March; but before
speaking of the approaching debate, I would
like to call attention to those that are past.
The late Dr. Herbert B. Adams was the
originator and first promoter of the interclass debates. Through his influence the
first was held in '98, and as the list of trophies testify, they have been continued yearly ever since. During this series each class
has not obtained an equal share of the
hdnors, as the following table shows
Year of Debate.

1899
1900

And moreover, the rewards have changed.
In '98 the victors were presented with medals; in '99, as one of the successful debaters
said: "There was a table full of books, a
big stack for each fellow, more than he could
lug off at one time." From that time the
custom of awarding books has been adhered
to; but the books are not presented until
some time after the debate. By this arrangement the members of the winning team are
allowed to select what books they wish.
This year much pleasure will be taken
away from the work by the absence of a feature of all past inter-class debates, namely,
Dr. Guy Carleton Lee. The students of '05
and '06 will be the first to hold a debate
without the encouragement of his presence;
though the memory of his energy, of his
striking personality, and of one or two stinging remarks by which he pointed out our
most glaring faults, will serve as a spur to
make us put forth our best efforts. I know
his absence is deeply regretted by both
classes, and I, for one, would go a long way
to meet once more his kindly smile and
cheery greeting.

But despite Dr. Lee's absence, as the debates have always awakened a keen interest
in the past, there is no doubt that such will
be the case in the present instance. Dr.
French has gained the respect and esteem of
both classes by the manner in which he has
conducted the correspondence with Brown;
and aided by his efforts we will no doubt live
up to the high standard of excellence set by
past debates.
As was the case last year, the same subject
has been chosen which, later on, will be used
for the debate with Brown. The subject is:
"Resolved, that the economic and political interests of the United States demand the
permanent retention of the Philippine
Islands."
The Seniors won the toss, and took the
east goal with the wind in their favor—I
mean they chose the negative side, the side
which the committee, composed of men from
both classes, had previously decided upon as
one Hopkins would take against Brown.
Among the Senior candidates are Goldman, chairman of '05 class team, also chairman of the inter-collegiate committee;
Cremen, secretary of '05 team; Stern, Bernstein, Zeigler, Straughn and Kohn.
Among the Junior candidates are C. Smith,
chairman of '06 team; Singewald, secretary
of inter-collegiate committee; Menzel, Hammond, Blondheim, Griffith, Robinson,Brauns,
Edlavitch, Matthews, Shackelford, Dickey
and Ruth.

EDITORIAL.
The editorial staff of the "Hullabaloo"
are hard at work on the new book for this
year, which promises to be a great success.
In one thing especially it will, if the idea is
properly supported, be an improvement on
its predecessors: there will be an attempt
to include in the book more material of interest to lower classmen, so that the book will
represent the whole University and not the
Senior Class alone. This result can only be
gained by the co-operation of the Junior and
Freshman classes, for of course it is very
hard for a Board composed wholly of Seniors
to discover and write up the various things
that would most appeal to lower classmen.
There has been a good deal of criticism of
the "Hullabaloo" in recent years by Juniors
and Freshmen on the ground that it was almost exclusively a chronicle of the adventures, wit and glories of the Senior Class,
and yet the very men who criticised the book
were the ones who might have helped to
make it broader in scope. The editors of the
1905 "Hullabaloo" are anxious to receive
contributions within the next two weeks—
such things as poems, stunts of various kinds
and drawings—from men in the Senior,
Junior and Freshman Classes. Poems may
be on any subject, the funnier the better,
and of any length, although the kind of serialpoem that comes in sections is discouraged.

The drawings should be done in India ink
on Bristol board about twice the size of
the finished reproduction. The "Hullabaloo"
Board is always glad to receive good
pictures of girls, and also drawings for the
titles of various subjects in the book. Even
if the contributors are not artists themselves,
almost everyone knows one or more people
who would be glad to do them some drawings for their year book if they were asked,
and therefore it is not a question of taking
any very great trouble about getting the
pictures. Nevertheless, drawings are very
hard to obtain, not on account of the scarcity
of artists, but simply because the artists'
friends are too lazy to ask for pictures. Of
course the "Hullabaloo" must of necessity
remain in large part a compilation of jokes
and "stunts" which are especially of interest
to the Seniors, but with a little trouble on the
part of every under-classman, it can be made
much more interesting both to themselves
and to their friends.
On the evening of Saturday, January 21,
the day after this issue is expected to come
from the press, the University will make its
debut in a new field of athletics. On this
evening the recently organized basket ball
team will begin its season with a game in
the cage against the University of Maryland.
The general enthusiasm basket ball has already awakened among the student-body
makes it unnecessary for the NEWS-LETTER
to attempt to "boom" the new sport. Nevertheless, the paper can not refrain from wishing the team the success it so richly deserves,
and calling upon the students to give it their
united support.
Every successful athletic team requires
three things: skillful players, money, and
With the first requisite, as an
friends.
article on another page clearly shows, the
basket ball team is bountifully supplied. To
provide the second and third is at once the
duty and privilege of the students. Moreover, the first game in a season is always an
occasion upon which a large attendance of
friendly rooters is peculiarly appropriate.
Such an attendance shows the player that
his hard work and his sacrifices preparatory
to making the team are appreciated, and that
his fellow-students trust in his ability to

THE NEWS-LETTER.
defend the good name of the Alma Mater;
he is strengthened and plays a better game
than he would otherwise be capable of. On
the other hand, the memory of a cold reception at the opening game is apt to cling to a
team and influence its work during the
whole season. An additional and equally,
potent reason makes a large attendance Saturday night desirable. This is the fact that
the management has pending arrangements
for a number of games with strong out-oftown teams requiring large guarantees. Until evidence is secured that the attendance
during the season will be large enough to
cover expenses, it would be folly for a team
without the financial backing of the Association to close the dates for these games.
Unless such evidence is given Saturday night
the games will have to be played away from
home.
It is the object of the basket ball team to
give its games social as well as athletic
standing. In other colleges basket ball is
a leading sport, and draws fashionable and
cultured audiences. Every precaution is being taken to put the contests here on the
highest possible level. No one, in the opinion of the 1\14w s-LvrTER, need hesitate to
bring a lady, and indeed, from present indications, the number present will be large.

INTERSTATE BIBLE STUDY
INSTITUTE.
The second annual Interstate Bible Study
Institute, arranged as a means of promoting
Bible study in the colleges of Maryland,
Delaware and the District of Columbia, was
successfully held in Levering Hall, January
13-15. There were thirty-five delegates from
out-of-town, representing the Christian Associations of six different institutions. The
Associations of Hopkins and the several medical schools in the city, furnished entertainment for the visitors.
The program provided for inspirational addresses, and for conferences to determine
the best methods of promoting Bible study,
especially during the remainder of the college year. Friday evening, Dr. G. W. Ward,
of Western Maryland College, spoke on "The
Claims of the Bible Upon College Men,"

and Saturday morning, Rev. W. F. Sheridan,
pastor of Mt. Vernon Place M. E. Church,
addressed the delegates on "The Benefit of
Personal Bible Study." Sunday morning,
Dr. Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College, conducted a model Bible class. Mr.
R. H. Edwards, of New York, for three years
General Secretary of the Yale Y. M. C. A.,
was present Friday and Saturday, and gave
many helpful suggestions. Other speakers
and leaders were: Messrs. W. H. Morriss,
General Secretary for Baltimore; H. T. Waller, Inter-collegiate Secretary for Baltimore;
J. M. Rice, Secretary B. & 0. Y. M. C. A.;
G. L. Curry, president of the Association at
Western Maryland College; and General
Secretary Addison.

MR. WRIGHT LORIMER'S VISIT.
Mr. Wright Lorimer, who is starring this
season in the "Shepherd King," which appeared at the Academy of Music last week,
addressed a large body of Hopkins students
in the Donovan Room, January 10th.
The speaker was introduced by Dr. French
of the Dept. of Public Speaking. The subject
of his address was "Literature as an Aid to
Public Speaking." Though rather undersized and of an exceedingly high-strung temperament, Mr. Lorimer's personality is a
striking one. His features are strong, and
his rich voice, trained to the demands of the
stage, is supported by an earnestness that
commands the attention of his hearers.
In his address he tried to confine himself
to the subject in hand, which, however, was
an unfortunate one, for time and again his
talk wandered off to the more pleasant fields
of his college life, and to his present task of
uplifting the stage. He spoke with feeling,
of the degeneracy which marks the American
theatre, and expressed confidence that a reaction would come about. He appealed to
students especially, he said, to use their higher culture to cultivate in others a taste for
a higher form of amusement, than that afforded by the present comic opera.
At the close of his address, Mr. Lorimer
was given a rousing "Gee-Hee, Gee-Haa,"
and seemed deeply moved by his reception.
He is the son of a Methodist minister and is
a graduate of the University of California.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

BASKET BALL.
Along with the general extension in athletics this year, the 'Varsity is to be represented also by a basket ball team. Captain
Holmes, who has worked energetically for
this sport ever since the University opened,
has been rewarded by a large number of
men coming out for practice. These men,
too, are not mere amateurs at the game, but
know the details thoroughly, and rank among
the best athletes in the country.
Captain Holmes himself is a noted basket
ball player. Last year he was captain of the
"Dixon" team, of New Orleans, and by his
skill and persistency made the team one of
the strongest in the State. Holmes is well
known among the 'varsity boys because of
his enthusiasm and his never-say-die spirit.
It is this spirit which has made basket ball
a factor in local sports. He canvassed the
medical department and succeeded in getting out a number of "stars," who, hitherto,
had considered their time too valuable to be
devoted to any form of athletics. These men,
with Captain Holmes, promise to make the
new sport popular at Hopkins.
Prominent among these men are McClure,
Helmholtz, Houghton, Boyd, Strohbar, Cole,
Williams, Taylor, Branham and Nichols.
McClure was former captain of Ohio State
University basket ball team, and is very
quick and accurate in his goal throwing.
Helmholtz is well known to the University
followers through his all around work in athletics. He and'Lyons, also a med., hold the
tennis championship in doubles of Maryland.
He was formerly captain of the University of
Wisconsin team. Houghton is a fourth year
med. and is an old Hopkins football player.
He was formerly captain of Ohio State Uni-

versity basket ball squad. Boyd, of baseball
and football fame, is a "star" man from the
University of Georgia. Strohbar is also a
very good man. His goal throwing at times
borders on the sensational. Cole, Williams,
Taylor, Branham and Nichols are good players, but have not had the experience of the
ex-captains.
The first game will be this Saturday night
(January 21) in the cage. The University
of Maryland boys, who have taken up the
sport this year, will be our opponents. It is
hoped that the 'varsity boys will turn out
and give the team a cheer, for they deserve
it. If the team is financially successful, the
manager promises us some rare treats in the
way of games with Cornell, Pennsylvania,
and other big teams.

THE TRACK TEAM OF 1905.
With the fixing of February 11 for the
annual indoor track and field meet to be
held in the "cage," regular work has begun
in training. Capt. Hill has his men out regularly three and four times a week now in order to have them in proper shape on the night
of the eleventh of February. This will be
the initial indoor meet of the season, and
in all probability it will be the only indoor
meet of any prominence held in the city this
winter. It was for a time hoped that the
spacious floor of the Fifth Regiment Armory
might have been secured for the purpose of
holding this meet, but owing to the fact that
it is occupied by one of the leading business
firms in the city its use was found to be
impossible.
Although the "cage" does not afford so
large a field as does the armory, it will be
a splendid place for holding the games. One

THE NEWS-LETTER.

advantage it has over the armory is that the
competitors may use spikes in the dirt floor.
The track ought to be in good condition by
the time of the meet, now that the curves are
being fixed up by new cinders being put on
the banks. There seems to be only one drawback, and that is that the straightaway
dashes will be necessarily short. With this
exception, every other condition is favorable,
and all things point toward this meet being
the most successful in the history of the
University.
A special effort will be made to have representatives from many of the larger universities which have the reputation of developing fast teams. Besides the entries that
are always made by the Georgetown University and the University of Pennsylvania,
it is hoped that entries will be made by other
colleges prominent in the athletic world. In
addition to these entries there will be the
usual number from the local clubs, "prep"
schools and colleges.
One question which is giving a great deal
of trouble at present is deciding who the
relay team will be that will be pitted against
Hopkins in the coming meet. Several universities are trying for this place, foremost
among them being Pennsylvania. The last
time Pennsylvania and Hopkins ran a relay
team against one another Hopkins won. This
makes "Penn" all the more anxious for such
a race, and there is no doubt of its furnishing
fine sport. Another candidate in the field
is Georgetown. Of the two races between
the Hopkins and Georgetown teams last season, each institution won one race. This
goes to show that the two teams are about
evenly matched, and it seems that a third
meeting is almost absolutely necessary in
order to decide the supremacy of the two
teams.
Other matters now before the track authorities are the considerations of dual track
meets with the Haverford College and the
Naval Academy. Negotiations with the.
Naval Academy are about off because no
suitable date can be fixed upon for holding
the meet. It is also probable that the proposed meet with Haverford will not materialize because Haverford wishes it to be held
on her own grounds, and the expenses accruing to such a trip would hardly justify
it. And so, all things being considered, it
seems that the dual meet with the University
of Virginia will be the only one Hopkins will
figure in this year.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

My Rhyming Dictionary.
I am the proudest person that just ever you did see,
I wonder if you could but guess what Santa brought to me;
Though if you scan these verses, it will be unnecessary
To tell you 'bout my fine new book—a rhyming dictionary.
Before I had this lovely gift from dear old Santa Claus,
I used to have to pause and think, and think and think and pause;
But now I copy down four rhymes from out this dictionary,
And just put anything before—as an auxiliary.
I do not have to search my brain to get the proper rhyme,
It's easier to look it up, and saves a lot of time;
The rhyme's the only thing that counts, the sense is secondary,
When I'm the proud possessor of a rhyming dictionary.
To prove to you what I can do, I'll show my primal try,
Of course I get much better as each day goes flitting by;
But the starter is the shortest that I ever had in stock,
The latter ones are quite too long, they stretch a city block!
Though my rhyming's not innate,
Yet I will not meditate,
That I am a reprobate,
Of the highest of the arts;
Though I ought to educate,
Instigate and innovate,
(My, but I am doing great,
Rhyming at an awful rate,)

Procrastinate and stipulate,
Celebrate and calculate—
But I'll really have to state,
That they're more than ninety-eight
Which can rhyme with prate and slate,
So I better had abate,
Lest relentless hand of Fate,
Throw the sharpest of her darts!

Of course the sense is lacking, but that doesn't matter much,
It is the rhyme we're after, not the writer's wordy touch;
Throw' learned logic to the dogs, for it is subsidiary,
It doesn't matter 'bout the sense with such a dictionary.
Bill Shakespeare should have had one when he wrote Lord Bacon's plays,
He could have rhymed with fine effect in very many ways;
Now anyone can pass him with a poor extemporary,
Of course, provided that he has a rhyming dictionary.
And Milton, Pope, and Dryden would have surely made a hit,
Had they owned the dictionary, and had rightly followed it;
But now to like their writings one must be an antiquary,
They never had a chance to buy a rhyming dictionary.
I haven't got the slightest doubt that I can beat them all,
For they are way, way out of date, 'tis I that have the call;
I will out-Shakespeare Milton—do every adversary,
Since I'm the proud possessor of a rhyming dictionary.

CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL night. The clubs left Frederick on Saturday
morning, arriving in Baltimore before noon;
CLUBS.
On Tuesday, December 27, at an early
hour in the morning, the musical clubs
boarded the train at Camden Station. The
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad had provided
a special car to accompany the clubs during.
the entire trip, and in this way the inconveniences of travel were much lessened. The
forty-mile trip to Washington was covered
with little incident.
At Washington the
car was coupled to another train; and in a
short while the run was made to Harper's
Ferry, and thence to Charlestown. In this
town, the men were boarded at a girls' seminary, and certainly everyone was royally
entertained. Especial thanks and honor are
due from all for the gastronomic treat so
kindly furnished by one ''inmate'' of the
seminary.
The concert at Charlestown was very successful, and was received in a most appreciative manner. At eleven o'clock Wednesday morning the clubs proceeded on their
journey. At Weverton, where there was a
wait of two hours, the men amused themselves by sliding on the ice. The concert
at Winchester was perhaps not as well received as the one given at Charlestown, but
the men had a pleasant time, and enjoyed
a fine "feed" after the duties of the evening
were over. The next town to be visited
was Hagerstown. There some of the fellows
amused themselves by advertising the concert in a way which one of the staid inhabitants said "lowered the dignity of the University," but which, to say the least, was perfectly harmless. The concert, which was
given at the hotel, was probably the best of
the trip, from the point of view of musical
excellence.
On Friday morning the men boarded the
train for Frederick, en route to which a stop
was made at Weverton, and a game of hockey
was enjoyed. The largest audience of the
four attended the concert at Frederick,
where a dance was given to the
men after the. entertainmentt. A supper was enjoyed by the clubs, after
the dance, through the kindness of Dr.
Whittle, and the thanks of all are due him
for this addition to the pleasures of the trip.
Some mild "stunts" were done by the
freshmen before the men adjourned for the

and thus a pleasant Christmas vacation was
completed.

THE TURNBULL AND HERTER
LECTURES.
The Turnbull Lectures will be given this
year by Dr. George E. Woodberry, lately professor of comparative literature at Columbia
University. There will be eight lectures,
the general subject being "The Poteic Forms
of Life."
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall
as follows:
Monday, March 27—"Illusion."
Tuesday, March 28—"The Poetic Form of
Nature."
Thursday, March 30—"The Poetic Form
of Intellect."
Friday, March 31—"The Poetic Form of
the Emotions."
Monday, April 3—"The Poetic Form of
the Will."
Tuesday, April 4—"The Affirmation of
Life."
Thursday, April 6—"The Denial of Life."
Friday, April 7—"Reality."
Dr. Woodberry is a graduate of Harvard,
and was for three years professor of English
in the University of Nebraska. He served
on the editorial staff of the "Nation" for a
year, and from 1891 to 1903 was professor
of comparative literature at Columbia. He
is well known as a writer both in poetry and
prose, and has edited valuable editions of
the works of a number of authors.
Dr. Hans H. Meyer, professor of pharmacology in the University of Vienna, has accepted the invitation to deliver the second
course of Herter Lectures next October. The
first course was given last spring by Prof.
Paul Ehrlich, of Frankfort-on-the-Main.
Professor Meyer ranks as one of the first
pharmacologists of the day. About a year
ago, in connection with Dr. Frederick Ransom, he made an important contribution to
the theory of the action of the poison of
tetanus, or lock-jaw.
Absent minded Professor—Gentlemen, I
have no time to call the roll to-day. Those
who are absent may simply hold up their
hands.

and who take no classical work in their

Professor Bailey, assistant professor of

$300 while others go as high as $3,000.

President Butler and Professor Brander
Matthews, of Columbia, at a recent banquet
at the Quill Club, in New York, predicted
that the universities of the future would be
in the largest cities. "No one to-day,"
said Brander Matthews, "would think of
founding a university at Ithaca, New Haven
or Princeton."

The News-Letter
Vol. IX.

January 20, 1905,

No. 6

A Hard Lesson.
"No, Frank; I do not expect you to admit
that all men are selfish. That would be asking too much; and then, you yourself will
always shine as a brilliant exception."
The man passed the reins into his right
hand and turned to the girl quickly, with
lips compressed, and an unmistakable frown
on his face. Then his mouth widened into
a smile.
"Edith, if you begin any more of your
sarcasm, I declare I'll turn the buggy into
the ditch, and set you in those blackberry
bushes. Why on earth do you talk such rot
—pardon me, but it is rot—just when I am
enjoying myself by airing my pet little
views? Moreover, you are scarcely respectful to your future lord and master."
The girl started. "Frank," she said suddenly, "how long have we been engaged?
Four months it has been, has it not? And
we are to be married in four weeks more.
Does it ever occur to you that we are making rathed rapid work of it? I have sometimes thought that it might be better, after
all, if—"
"What might be better?" He watched
her closely as her eyes fell to her left hand.
"Oh, nothing;" and he knew from the answer and the tone that coaxing would be
of no use.
"Edith, do you see those two men in the
yellow trap just ahead? Well, the one in
the gray clothes is Charlie Hanson, who sold
me this horse. I heard from a mutual acquaintance that he gave himself grand airs
after the deal, because he had got the best
of the bargain. Now, I think I'm a pretty
good judge of horses, and I'm willing to bet
that this horse is worth the money I paid
for her."
"Naturally;" said the girl, "or you would
not have paid it."
The man did not heed the interruption,
and went on, "Let's catch up to them. I

want to see what sort of a nag he's driving
to-day."
He flicked the reins on the horse's back,
and the carriages came side by side. The
two men greeted each other coldly, and presently—after the three-cornered introduction
was over—Frank threw out a feeler.
"Charlie, this is a pretty good mare you
sold me. She's speedy at times. She showed
2.32 at the track last week. Is that one
yours?" pointing to the other horse.
"Yes," was the answer. "I got her last
month, and she's rather fast. Suppose we
try them together—say to the next milehouse."
"Done," was the reply, and each whipped
up his horse.
Selfishness is a trait which manifests itself in a variety of ways. Some men it
makes conceited. Others become lazy because of it. Still other men are drawn by
it to seek an eternal good time. To the third
class belonged Frank Doane. He prided
himself on his "sporting instincts," which,
being examined, comprised solely a desire
for pleasure at the expense of anything else;
and anything else might include his friends,
his money, or, at present, the girl he was to
marry. As the light buggy was flying down
the road, almost abreast of the other team,
he forgot Edith and everything except the
fact that he had been challenged to a race,
and must do his best to win it. He did not
allow the idea of danger to enter his head.
The road was clear, he was an experienced
driver, and there could be no danger. As
for asking Edith's permission, it seemed entirely unnecessary.
He laid the whip on heavily, until the
carriage rocked like a row boat as it bounded
over stones and ruts. Yet the other horse
kept just a few yards ahead. Hanson kept
a firm hold on the reins, and looked back
over his shoulder with a smile which drove

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Doane to let his horse have full control of the
bit. The speed was frightful, and increased
every second. The mile-house was passed
in no time. The slower horse, no longer
feeling any curb, took matters entirely into
her own control, so that when a mounted
policeman shouted a caution as the flying
pair flashed by, Doane found it impossible
to check the mad pace of the mare, who was
now almost winded and covered with foam.
Hanson, however, had perfect control of his
horse, and slowed down to a walk.
Edith had not made a sound. With hands
fast gripped to the seat, and with her face
set, she was like a statue, expecting every
moment to be hurled from the buggy, but
showing not a trace of her emotions in her
features. She saw a speed-sign far down
the road come nearer, and disappear in a
blur. Vehicles were drawn off to both sides
of the driveway, and she saw the frightened
faces of the occupants and realized her danger. But danger did not occupy most of
her thoughts. She was wondering most at
the man by her side. His hat had blown
off, his eyes were straining, his whole soul
absorbed in his mad pleasure.
She was
having his whole real self revealed to her.
In the parlor, Frank Doane was the smoothest, most self-contained man to be found.
Now, he would not have heeded a pistol at
his head, so entirely had he lost control of
himself. This man was not the one she had
admired for his steady hold on himself, for
his thoughtfulness for women, and for his
bravery and gentleness. No; the creature
by her side was little better than one of the
howlIng, maddened crowd she had once seen
at a race. And she was to marry him in
a month. She shuddered at the thought.
Both Frank and the horse had by this time
gotten their fill of racing; and as the horse
was nearly run tired,. it slackened its speed.
The girl pointed to a large automobile
about two hundred yards distant, which was
rapidly approaching. As the space closed,
the horse began to step sideways and to
shy; and the buggy was slewed around and
went upon two wheels. It hung there for
a few awful seconds, and then, as the terrified animal gave a final spring, it turned
over into the ditch, tearing loose the traces,

and threw the man and woman into the
hedge beside the road. The horse continued
its flight. Neither person was much hurt,
and both rose. Edith with her silk skirt
in tatters, and Frank with a badly scratched
face. His apologies were profuse and pitiful. to hear. Miss Lawton received them
with a perfectly calm face.
"Let us get to the cars," was all she said,
and made her way through the crowd.
Doane made arrangements with Charlie Hanson, who had by this time overtaken them,
to bring the carriage home, and to look after
the horse, which had been stopped a short
distance down the road and was now being
led back. Frank had a great desire to lay
violent hands on Hanson, who, with earnest
inquiries as to whether Miss Lawton was
hurt, and sincerest regrets that he had been
so foolish as to propose the race, was quick
to offer his services to get the horse and
buggy home. Frank felt that -his position
was very uncomfortable. He knew that, in
the eyes of his fiancee, he had lowered himself irrevocably; and in the eyes of the
crowd around him he had let a horse run
away and upset a woman, so that he was
deserving of no pity. Hanson's horse had
beaten his, and this was another sting. With
a very full sense of having done a poor day's
work, and feeling very small indeed, he accompanied Miss Lawton to the electric cars.
The ride home was almost in silence. Both
had learned a lesson, and were thinking over
what they had learned. When Miss Lawton's home was reached, she extended him
her hand, saying with a smile that nettled
him, "You will pardon me if I do not ask
you to come in. I suppose I have enjoyed
the drive. Good afternoon."
The door closed in his face.
Doane called at her house that evening.
Her brother met him at the door.
"Why, Frank, Edith left just a few minutes ago for her aunt's in Washington. No,
she didn't seem to be hurt in the least. And,
by the way, she told me to give you this if
you came to-night. She said you would understand." He handed him a small pasteboard box. It contained her engagement
ring, and he understood.

The Conference of The Association of American Universities.
NE of the most important events that
have occurred recently at the University took place when the sixth
annual session of the Association of
American Universities was held here.
during the latter part of last week.
Many of the most distinguished figures in
the colleges of the United States were present as delegates from their respective Universities. Six of the delegates were presidents of universities, and the others were
professors of wide renown in their own fields
of research and teaching.
. Tile conference began on Thursday of last
week. The sessions, which were held in the
Donovan room, were not public, because the
subjects under consideration were of great
importance, and could be more thoroughly
discussed than if the public had been admitted to the meetings. After the first session the delegates were entertained at lunch
by the trustees and professors of this University. The tables were placed in McCoy Hall,
which was beautifully banked with palms.
In the evening Mr. Theodore Marburg gave
a reception for the delegates at his house on
Mt. Vernon Place.
On Friday morning the conference assembled in the Donovan room. Among the subjects discussed was that of the higher technical education and the instruction in graduate schools.
President Remsen believes
that the length of time needed to prepare
for and complete a modern professional
course is too great. In the first place, the
age of graduation from the leading colleges
in this country is becoming so high that students cannot begin their professional training until they are twenty-two or twentythree on the average. Then, too, the length
of the professional courses themselves is now
so great that some of the best years of a
man's life are taken up with preparatory
work. President Remsen believes that in so
far as it tends to prevent students from beginning their . professional or business life
until they are twenty-two or twenty-three,
the present system of college training is seriously defective.
The closing session of the conference was
held on Saturday morning and at it papers
were read on "Opportunities for Higher Ed-

0

ucation" and "Research in State Universities." President Van use of the University of Wisconsin said that he held that in
the future the State Universities would be in
a much stronger position with reference to
advanced instructtion. A number of States,
he said, are now granting large sums to their
universities for advanced instruction and research, and in the future State funds for such
purposes are sure to greatly increase in
amount.
Professor Page of the University of Virginia, gave an encouraging account of the
increase in the resources of the Southern
State Universities. The people of the South,
he said, favor strong support of such institutions.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Heroines, Heroes and Villains in Modern Fiction.
More than in price, more than in the manner of publication, more than in any particular connected plot, letter-press, or sale, has
the novel of to-day changed from its predecessor of a generation ago, in the character
of its heroine. Our mothers and fathers
used to read in their novels of heroines of
the fragile, clinging kind, who had "willowy forms, and great, trustful eyes;" heroines who could moralize ever so learnedly
on almost any abstract subject, and reinforce
their opinions by numberless quotations from
classic authors, yet who were content to be
guided, in all temporal matters, entirely by
members of the stronger sex; heroines who
fainted upon almost no provocation, wept
upon no provocation at all, and, in the last
chapter, generally accepted the hero's proposal of marriage by bursting into a flood
of glad tears, and fainting in his arms. The
hero, as befitted the Romeo of such a Juliet,
was usually strong and brave, and "full of
a quiet dignity' —a veritable oak for such a
drooping vine of a heroine to hold fast to.
The modern heroine has got bravely over
all this. No sitting at home embroidering
samplers, no poetic hours spent in painting
landscapes, or in reading sentimental poetry,
for her! She is an "athletic girl," who plays
golf and tennis, rides a bicycle, or manages
her, own automobile, and is, on the whole,
quite as well able to take care of herself, as
The "Gibson
any of her male friends.
girl," the "Christy girl," and half-a-dozen
other kinds of independent and very muscular girls, now hold the stage, from which
their elder sister, with her hoop-skirts and
vapors, has fled in dismay.
A corresponding change has taken place
in the hero. He must still be strong and
brave, but principally in a physical sense.
He must be a very paladin for dash and
vigor—equally ready to rescue a lady, shoot
down a villain, or play the part of a king.
When he was at college, he was, of course,
captain of the 'varsity crew, or of the foot-

ball team! Of course, also, he had, and still
has, an infinite contempt for books! The
very first achievement of the hero of Richard
Harding Davis' latest novel, "Captain Macklin," was to get himself expelled from college.
Nor has the evolution of the villain been
less rapid or far-reaching than that of the
other principals in the story. No longer do
we meet with the scheming Shylock, or the
loathsome Uriah Heep, any more than we
meet with the womanly Portia, or the gentle
Agnes Wakefield. The crafty, serpent-like
kind of villain has given place to a villain
moulded from much the same .knock-medown-and-drag-me-out sort of material as
the hero is. The up-to-date villain glories
in making midnight attempts to abduct the
heroine, in attacking the hero with a band of
cut-throats, and in comporting himself generally in such a manner that the hero may
have plenty of opportunity to show his mettle. Ile is equally as ready as the villain of
old, to lie, steal, murder, or do anything else
that is evil; but he is, in addition, the possessor of a personality of the most dare-devil,
brigand-like type—just as a villain should
be in these strenuous times. He nearly always has to be killed in the last chapter, by
the hero, in order to be gotten rid of.
In the matter of personal appearance, heroines, heroes, And villains have all changed
less than in any other particular. Though now
strong and buxom, the heroine is still the
possessor, in most cases, of a "face which is
a perfect oval," "rose-bud lips," a "silvery
voice," and "rebellious curls." The hero
is tall and broad-sohuldered, usually has
curly hair, and, especially with women novelists, has the "profile of a Greek god." Villains still have "a cast in one eye," or are
"hatchet-faced;" but, on the whole, they
exhibit a far greater variety of types than
either the hero or heroine.
A Literary Critic.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE INTER-CLASS DEBATE.
NE of the many subjects of talk, among

O

the little groups which gather in the
corridors of McCoy Hall, is the coming inter-class debate. This will take place
during the second week in March; but before
speaking of the approaching debate, I would
like to call attention to those that are past.
The late Dr. Herbert B. Adams was the
originator and first promoter of the interclass debates. Through his influence the
first was held in '98, and as the list of trophies testify, they have been continued yearly ever since. During this series each class
has not obtained an equal share of the
hdnors, as the following table shows

And moreover, the rewards have changed.
In '98 the victors were presented with medals; in '99, as one of the successful debaters
said: "There was a table full of books, a
big stack for each fellow, more than he could
lug off at one time." From that time the
custom of awarding books has been adhered
to; but the books are not presented until
some time after the debate. By this arrangement the members of the winning team are
allowed to select what books they wish.
This year much pleasure will be taken
away from the work by the absence of a feature of all past inter-class debates, namely,
Dr. Guy Carleton Lee. The students of '05
and '06 will be the first to hold a debate
without the encouragement of his presence;
though the memory of his energy, of his
striking personality, and of one or two stinging remarks by which he pointed out our
most glaring faults, will serve as a spur to
make us put forth our best efforts. I know
his absence is deeply regretted by both
classes, and I, for one, would go a long way
to meet once more his kindly smile and
cheery greeting.

But despite Dr. Lee's absence, as the debates have always awakened a keen interest
in the past, there is no doubt that such will
be the case in the present instance. Dr.
French has gained the respect and esteem of
both classes by the manner in which he has
conducted the correspondence with Brown;
and aided by his efforts we will no doubt live
up to the high standard of excellence set by
past debates.
As was the case last year, the same subject
has been chosen which, later on, will be used
for the debate with Brown. The subject is:
"Resolved, that the economic and political interests of the United States demand the
permanent retention of the Philippine
Islands."
The Seniors won the toss, and took the
east goal with the wind in their favor—I
mean they chose the negative side, the side
which the committee, composed of men from
both classes, had previously decided upon as
one Hopkins would take against Brown.
Among the Senior candidates are Goldman, chairman of '05 class team, also chairman of the inter-collegiate committee;
Cremen, secretary of '05 team; Stern, Bernstein, Zeigler, Straughn and Kohn.
Among the Junior candidates are C. Smith,
chairman of '06 team; Singewald, secretary
of inter-collegiate committee; Menzel, Hammond, Blondheim, Griffith, Robinson,Brauns,
Edlavitch, Matthews, Shackelford, Dickey
and Ruth.

EDITORIAL.
The editorial staff of the "Hullabaloo"
are hard at work on the new book for this
year, which promises to be a great success.
In one thing especially it will, if the idea is
properly supported, be an improvement on
its predecessors: there will be an attempt
to include in the book more material of interest to lower classmen, so that the book will
represent the whole University and not the
Senior Class alone. This result can only be
gained by the co-operation of the Junior and
Freshman classes, for of course it is very
hard for a Board composed wholly of Seniors
to discover and write up the various things
that would most appeal to lower classmen.
There has been a good deal of criticism of
the "Hullabaloo" in recent years by Juniors
and Freshmen on the ground that it was almost exclusively a chronicle of the adventures, wit and glories of the Senior Class,
and yet the very men who criticised the book
were the ones who might have helped to
make it broader in scope. The editors of the
1905 "Hullabaloo" are anxious to receive
contributions within the next two weeks—
such things as poems, stunts of various kinds
and drawings—from men in the Senior,
Junior and Freshman Classes. Poems may
be on any subject, the funnier the better,
and of any length, although the kind of serialpoem that comes in sections is discouraged.

The drawings should be done in India ink
on Bristol board about twice the size of
the finished reproduction. The "Hullabaloo"
Board is always glad to receive good
pictures of girls, and also drawings for the
titles of various subjects in the book. Even
if the contributors are not artists themselves,
almost everyone knows one or more people
who would be glad to do them some drawings for their year book if they were asked,
and therefore it is not a question of taking
any very great trouble about getting the
pictures. Nevertheless, drawings are very
hard to obtain, not on account of the scarcity
of artists, but simply because the artists'
friends are too lazy to ask for pictures. Of
course the "Hullabaloo" must of necessity
remain in large part a compilation of jokes
and "stunts" which are especially of interest
to the Seniors, but with a little trouble on the
part of every under-classman, it can be made
much more interesting both to themselves
and to their friends.
On the evening of Saturday, January 21,
the day after this issue is expected to come
from the press, the University will make its
debut in a new field of athletics. On this
evening the recently organized basket ball
team will begin its season with a game in
the cage against the University of Maryland.
The general enthusiasm basket ball has already awakened among the student-body
makes it unnecessary for the NEWS-LETTER
to attempt to "boom" the new sport. Nevertheless, the paper can not refrain from wishing the team the success it so richly deserves,
and calling upon the students to give it their
united support.
Every successful athletic team requires
three things: skillful players, money, and
With the first requisite, as an
friends.
article on another page clearly shows, the
basket ball team is bountifully supplied. To
provide the second and third is at once the
duty and privilege of the students. Moreover, the first game in a season is always an
occasion upon which a large attendance of
friendly rooters is peculiarly appropriate.
Such an attendance shows the player that
his hard work and his sacrifices preparatory
to making the team are appreciated, and that
his fellow-students trust in his ability to

THE NEWS-LETTER.
defend the good name of the Alma Mater;
he is strengthened and plays a better game
than he would otherwise be capable of. On
the other hand, the memory of a cold reception at the opening game is apt to cling to a
team and influence its work during the
whole season. An additional and equally,
potent reason makes a large attendance Saturday night desirable. This is the fact that
the management has pending arrangements
for a number of games with strong out-oftown teams requiring large guarantees. Until evidence is secured that the attendance
during the season will be large enough to
cover expenses, it would be folly for a team
without the financial backing of the Association to close the dates for these games.
Unless such evidence is given Saturday night
the games will have to be played away from
home.
It is the object of the basket ball team to
give its games social as well as athletic
standing. In other colleges basket ball is
a leading sport, and draws fashionable and
cultured audiences. Every precaution is being taken to put the contests here on the
highest possible level. No one, in the opinion of the 1\14w s-LvrTER, need hesitate to
bring a lady, and indeed, from present indications, the number present will be large.

INTERSTATE BIBLE STUDY
INSTITUTE.
The second annual Interstate Bible Study
Institute, arranged as a means of promoting
Bible study in the colleges of Maryland,
Delaware and the District of Columbia, was
successfully held in Levering Hall, January
13-15. There were thirty-five delegates from
out-of-town, representing the Christian Associations of six different institutions. The
Associations of Hopkins and the several medical schools in the city, furnished entertainment for the visitors.
The program provided for inspirational addresses, and for conferences to determine
the best methods of promoting Bible study,
especially during the remainder of the college year. Friday evening, Dr. G. W. Ward,
of Western Maryland College, spoke on "The
Claims of the Bible Upon College Men,"

and Saturday morning, Rev. W. F. Sheridan,
pastor of Mt. Vernon Place M. E. Church,
addressed the delegates on "The Benefit of
Personal Bible Study." Sunday morning,
Dr. Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College, conducted a model Bible class. Mr.
R. H. Edwards, of New York, for three years
General Secretary of the Yale Y. M. C. A.,
was present Friday and Saturday, and gave
many helpful suggestions. Other speakers
and leaders were: Messrs. W. H. Morriss,
General Secretary for Baltimore; H. T. Waller, Inter-collegiate Secretary for Baltimore;
J. M. Rice, Secretary B. & 0. Y. M. C. A.;
G. L. Curry, president of the Association at
Western Maryland College; and General
Secretary Addison.

MR. WRIGHT LORIMER'S VISIT.
Mr. Wright Lorimer, who is starring this
season in the "Shepherd King," which appeared at the Academy of Music last week,
addressed a large body of Hopkins students
in the Donovan Room, January 10th.
The speaker was introduced by Dr. French
of the Dept. of Public Speaking. The subject
of his address was "Literature as an Aid to
Public Speaking." Though rather undersized and of an exceedingly high-strung temperament, Mr. Lorimer's personality is a
striking one. His features are strong, and
his rich voice, trained to the demands of the
stage, is supported by an earnestness that
commands the attention of his hearers.
In his address he tried to confine himself
to the subject in hand, which, however, was
an unfortunate one, for time and again his
talk wandered off to the more pleasant fields
of his college life, and to his present task of
uplifting the stage. He spoke with feeling,
of the degeneracy which marks the American
theatre, and expressed confidence that a reaction would come about. He appealed to
students especially, he said, to use their higher culture to cultivate in others a taste for
a higher form of amusement, than that afforded by the present comic opera.
At the close of his address, Mr. Lorimer
was given a rousing "Gee-Hee, Gee-Haa,"
and seemed deeply moved by his reception.
He is the son of a Methodist minister and is
a graduate of the University of California.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

BASKET BALL.
Along with the general extension in athletics this year, the 'Varsity is to be represented also by a basket ball team. Captain
Holmes, who has worked energetically for
this sport ever since the University opened,
has been rewarded by a large number of
men coming out for practice. These men,
too, are not mere amateurs at the game, but
know the details thoroughly, and rank among
the best athletes in the country.
Captain Holmes himself is a noted basket
ball player. Last year he was captain of the
"Dixon" team, of New Orleans, and by his
skill and persistency made the team one of
the strongest in the State. Holmes is well
known among the 'varsity boys because of
his enthusiasm and his never-say-die spirit.
It is this spirit which has made basket ball
a factor in local sports. He canvassed the
medical department and succeeded in getting out a number of "stars," who, hitherto,
had considered their time too valuable to be
devoted to any form of athletics. These men,
with Captain Holmes, promise to make the
new sport popular at Hopkins.
Prominent among these men are McClure,
Helmholtz, Houghton, Boyd, Strohbar, Cole,
Williams, Taylor, Branham and Nichols.
McClure was former captain of Ohio State
University basket ball team, and is very
quick and accurate in his goal throwing.
Helmholtz is well known to the University
followers through his all around work in athletics. He and'Lyons, also a med., hold the
tennis championship in doubles of Maryland.
He was formerly captain of the University of
Wisconsin team. Houghton is a fourth year
med. and is an old Hopkins football player.
He was formerly captain of Ohio State Uni-

versity basket ball squad. Boyd, of baseball
and football fame, is a "star" man from the
University of Georgia. Strohbar is also a
very good man. His goal throwing at times
borders on the sensational. Cole, Williams,
Taylor, Branham and Nichols are good players, but have not had the experience of the
ex-captains.
The first game will be this Saturday night
(January 21) in the cage. The University
of Maryland boys, who have taken up the
sport this year, will be our opponents. It is
hoped that the 'varsity boys will turn out
and give the team a cheer, for they deserve
it. If the team is financially successful, the
manager promises us some rare treats in the
way of games with Cornell, Pennsylvania,
and other big teams.

THE TRACK TEAM OF 1905.
With the fixing of February 11 for the
annual indoor track and field meet to be
held in the "cage," regular work has begun
in training. Capt. Hill has his men out regularly three and four times a week now in order to have them in proper shape on the night
of the eleventh of February. This will be
the initial indoor meet of the season, and
in all probability it will be the only indoor
meet of any prominence held in the city this
winter. It was for a time hoped that the
spacious floor of the Fifth Regiment Armory
might have been secured for the purpose of
holding this meet, but owing to the fact that
it is occupied by one of the leading business
firms in the city its use was found to be
impossible.
Although the "cage" does not afford so
large a field as does the armory, it will be
a splendid place for holding the games. One

THE NEWS-LETTER.

advantage it has over the armory is that the
competitors may use spikes in the dirt floor.
The track ought to be in good condition by
the time of the meet, now that the curves are
being fixed up by new cinders being put on
the banks. There seems to be only one drawback, and that is that the straightaway
dashes will be necessarily short. With this
exception, every other condition is favorable,
and all things point toward this meet being
the most successful in the history of the
University.
A special effort will be made to have representatives from many of the larger universities which have the reputation of developing fast teams. Besides the entries that
are always made by the Georgetown University and the University of Pennsylvania,
it is hoped that entries will be made by other
colleges prominent in the athletic world. In
addition to these entries there will be the
usual number from the local clubs, "prep"
schools and colleges.
One question which is giving a great deal
of trouble at present is deciding who the
relay team will be that will be pitted against
Hopkins in the coming meet. Several universities are trying for this place, foremost
among them being Pennsylvania. The last
time Pennsylvania and Hopkins ran a relay
team against one another Hopkins won. This
makes "Penn" all the more anxious for such
a race, and there is no doubt of its furnishing
fine sport. Another candidate in the field
is Georgetown. Of the two races between
the Hopkins and Georgetown teams last season, each institution won one race. This
goes to show that the two teams are about
evenly matched, and it seems that a third
meeting is almost absolutely necessary in
order to decide the supremacy of the two
teams.
Other matters now before the track authorities are the considerations of dual track
meets with the Haverford College and the
Naval Academy. Negotiations with the.
Naval Academy are about off because no
suitable date can be fixed upon for holding
the meet. It is also probable that the proposed meet with Haverford will not materialize because Haverford wishes it to be held
on her own grounds, and the expenses accruing to such a trip would hardly justify
it. And so, all things being considered, it
seems that the dual meet with the University
of Virginia will be the only one Hopkins will
figure in this year.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

My Rhyming Dictionary.
I am the proudest person that just ever you did see,
I wonder if you could but guess what Santa brought to me;
Though if you scan these verses, it will be unnecessary
To tell you 'bout my fine new book—a rhyming dictionary.
Before I had this lovely gift from dear old Santa Claus,
I used to have to pause and think, and think and think and pause;
But now I copy down four rhymes from out this dictionary,
And just put anything before—as an auxiliary.
I do not have to search my brain to get the proper rhyme,
It's easier to look it up, and saves a lot of time;
The rhyme's the only thing that counts, the sense is secondary,
When I'm the proud possessor of a rhyming dictionary.
To prove to you what I can do, I'll show my primal try,
Of course I get much better as each day goes flitting by;
But the starter is the shortest that I ever had in stock,
The latter ones are quite too long, they stretch a city block!
Though my rhyming's not innate,
Yet I will not meditate,
That I am a reprobate,
Of the highest of the arts;
Though I ought to educate,
Instigate and innovate,
(My, but I am doing great,
Rhyming at an awful rate,)

Procrastinate and stipulate,
Celebrate and calculate—
But I'll really have to state,
That they're more than ninety-eight
Which can rhyme with prate and slate,
So I better had abate,
Lest relentless hand of Fate,
Throw the sharpest of her darts!

Of course the sense is lacking, but that doesn't matter much,
It is the rhyme we're after, not the writer's wordy touch;
Throw' learned logic to the dogs, for it is subsidiary,
It doesn't matter 'bout the sense with such a dictionary.
Bill Shakespeare should have had one when he wrote Lord Bacon's plays,
He could have rhymed with fine effect in very many ways;
Now anyone can pass him with a poor extemporary,
Of course, provided that he has a rhyming dictionary.
And Milton, Pope, and Dryden would have surely made a hit,
Had they owned the dictionary, and had rightly followed it;
But now to like their writings one must be an antiquary,
They never had a chance to buy a rhyming dictionary.
I haven't got the slightest doubt that I can beat them all,
For they are way, way out of date, 'tis I that have the call;
I will out-Shakespeare Milton—do every adversary,
Since I'm the proud possessor of a rhyming dictionary.

CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL night. The clubs left Frederick on Saturday
morning, arriving in Baltimore before noon;
CLUBS.
On Tuesday, December 27, at an early
hour in the morning, the musical clubs
boarded the train at Camden Station. The
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad had provided
a special car to accompany the clubs during.
the entire trip, and in this way the inconveniences of travel were much lessened. The
forty-mile trip to Washington was covered
with little incident.
At Washington the
car was coupled to another train; and in a
short while the run was made to Harper's
Ferry, and thence to Charlestown. In this
town, the men were boarded at a girls' seminary, and certainly everyone was royally
entertained. Especial thanks and honor are
due from all for the gastronomic treat so
kindly furnished by one ''inmate'' of the
seminary.
The concert at Charlestown was very successful, and was received in a most appreciative manner. At eleven o'clock Wednesday morning the clubs proceeded on their
journey. At Weverton, where there was a
wait of two hours, the men amused themselves by sliding on the ice. The concert
at Winchester was perhaps not as well received as the one given at Charlestown, but
the men had a pleasant time, and enjoyed
a fine "feed" after the duties of the evening
were over. The next town to be visited
was Hagerstown. There some of the fellows
amused themselves by advertising the concert in a way which one of the staid inhabitants said "lowered the dignity of the University," but which, to say the least, was perfectly harmless. The concert, which was
given at the hotel, was probably the best of
the trip, from the point of view of musical
excellence.
On Friday morning the men boarded the
train for Frederick, en route to which a stop
was made at Weverton, and a game of hockey
was enjoyed. The largest audience of the
four attended the concert at Frederick,
where a dance was given to the
men after the. entertainmentt. A supper was enjoyed by the clubs, after
the dance, through the kindness of Dr.
Whittle, and the thanks of all are due him
for this addition to the pleasures of the trip.
Some mild "stunts" were done by the
freshmen before the men adjourned for the

and thus a pleasant Christmas vacation was
completed.

THE TURNBULL AND HERTER
LECTURES.
The Turnbull Lectures will be given this
year by Dr. George E. Woodberry, lately professor of comparative literature at Columbia
University. There will be eight lectures,
the general subject being "The Poteic Forms
of Life."
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall
as follows:
Monday, March 27—"Illusion."
Tuesday, March 28—"The Poetic Form of
Nature."
Thursday, March 30—"The Poetic Form
of Intellect."
Friday, March 31—"The Poetic Form of
the Emotions."
Monday, April 3—"The Poetic Form of
the Will."
Tuesday, April 4—"The Affirmation of
Life."
Thursday, April 6—"The Denial of Life."
Friday, April 7—"Reality."
Dr. Woodberry is a graduate of Harvard,
and was for three years professor of English
in the University of Nebraska. He served
on the editorial staff of the "Nation" for a
year, and from 1891 to 1903 was professor
of comparative literature at Columbia. He
is well known as a writer both in poetry and
prose, and has edited valuable editions of
the works of a number of authors.
Dr. Hans H. Meyer, professor of pharmacology in the University of Vienna, has accepted the invitation to deliver the second
course of Herter Lectures next October. The
first course was given last spring by Prof.
Paul Ehrlich, of Frankfort-on-the-Main.
Professor Meyer ranks as one of the first
pharmacologists of the day. About a year
ago, in connection with Dr. Frederick Ransom, he made an important contribution to
the theory of the action of the poison of
tetanus, or lock-jaw.
Absent minded Professor—Gentlemen, I
have no time to call the roll to-day. Those
who are absent may simply hold up their
hands.

and who take no classical work in their

Professor Bailey, assistant professor of

$300 while others go as high as $3,000.

President Butler and Professor Brander
Matthews, of Columbia, at a recent banquet
at the Quill Club, in New York, predicted
that the universities of the future would be
in the largest cities. "No one to-day,"
said Brander Matthews, "would think of
founding a university at Ithaca, New Haven
or Princeton."
